issues.description: The problem statement's UML specifies getNumberOfStudentsPerTutor() to return a double, but the solution implementation declares and returns an int. This mismatch in return type will confuse students about the expected return type and numeric semantics (integer division vs. floating-point division). Students following the UML will implement a double-returning method (and expect fractional values), while the solution uses integer division which discards fractional results — this can cause failing checks or unexpected behavior.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the implementation with the UML in the problem statement: change the method signature in the solution (and template guidance) to return double (public double getNumberOfStudentsPerTutor()) and compute using floating-point division, e.g. return (double) getTotalNumberOfStudents() / getNumberOfTutors(); also consider handling the case when numberOfTutors == 0 (e.g. return 0.0 or throw an IllegalStateException) to avoid division-by-zero.
